abstract.text: Learn how you can use the latest improvements to Safari Web Extensions to create even better experiences for people browsing the web. Weâ€™ll show you how to upgrade to manifest version 3, adopt the latest APIs for Web Extensions, and sync extensions across devices.

metadata.title: Whatâ€™s new in Safari Web Extensions

inlineContent.text: next iteration of the web extension platform
introduces performance and security improvements and consolidates popular extension APIs
supported from Safari 15.4 (you can keep using version 2 if your platform target is lower)

content.text: Use of service workers instead of background pages

inlineContent.text: service workers are event driven pages where you can register listeners using the
compatible with other browsers
substitute with non-persistent background pages

content.text: APIs for executing JavaScript and styling on a web page have moved from the tabs API to the new scripting API

inlineContent.text: most functionality stays the same
new ways to inject code on a webpage
more options for which frames on the page the code should be executed in
ability to decide which execution environment the code should run in
Version 2:

code: frameId: 1,                                      // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» supports only one id
code: "document.body.style.background = 'blue';" // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» can only inject code that's contained in a string

inlineContent.text: Version 3:

code: target: { tabId: 1, frameIds: [ 1 ] }, // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» supports multiple ids
func: changeBackgroundColor,           // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» we can pass along a function object containing this code, instead of just a string
args: [ "blue" ]                       // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» we can pass arguments to the function

inlineContent.text: Version 2:

code: file: "file.js" // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» can specify only one file

inlineContent.text: Version 3:

code: files: [ "file.js", "file2.js" ] // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» can specify multiple file

inlineContent.text: Like above, we can now add/remove multiple files:
Add styling:
Remove styling:
In version 2, every resource you include can be accessed by any website you specify in the Manifest.
In version 3, you can specify which resource is available in which website:
set version 3 in
in your
manifest.json
file
manually migrate any of the APIs seen above
run your extension and inspect it to get access to the console and see if there are any error messages
Declarative net request is a content blocking API that provides web extensions with a fast and privacy preserving way to block or modify network requests using rulesets
these rules are defined in the manifest file
V2: up to 10 rulesets, V3: up to 50 rulesets
only 10 rulesets can be enabled at any given time (you can set
in the rules declaration in the manifest)

code: // Rules that won't persist across browser sessions or extension updates
// Rules that will persist across browser sessions or extension updates

inlineContent.text: allows websites to create custom behavior if the user has your extension enabled
you declare match patterns in the Manifest:

code: "matches": ["*://*.apple.com/*"] // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» determines which pages can communicate with your extension

inlineContent.text: must use the browser namespace
user must grant permission
In the website:

code: // ðŸ‘‡ðŸ» you must use this id format "app.extension.id (appstore.team.id)"
// ðŸ‘†ðŸ» you will have different IDs for other browsers
function(response) {    // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» callback to handle response
console.log("Received response from the background page:");

inlineContent.text: In the extension (background page/session):

code: sendResponse({ farewell: "Goodbye!" }); // ðŸ‘ˆðŸ» send a message back

inlineContent.text: Because your extension will have a different id in different browsers, in the browser your website can use an helper function to determine which id to use:

code: resolve({ extensionID: extensionID, isInstalled: true, response: response });

inlineContent.text: In the extension:
no longer 10 MB quota per extension
you can use as much data as you see fit
users can clear extension data at any given time
add the following permission in your manifest:
if a user turns on your extension on one of their devices, itâ€™ll be turned on on all of their devices
easier extension download (in the settings.app, you can enable to automatically download/enable extensions)
automatic if your extension is an universal purchase (available on all platforms)
if you donâ€™t use universal purchase, you can manually link your apps:

abstract.text: Join us for an update on Swift. Weâ€™ll take you through performance improvements, explore more secure and extensible Swift packages, and share advancements in Swift concurrency. Weâ€™ll also introduce you to Swift Regex, better generics, and other tools built into the language to help you write more flexible & expressive code.

Weâ€™ll take you through the latest updates to CloudKit Console and discover how you can explore and debug your containers on the web like never before. Learn more about Act as iCloud, which helps you query records and view data from the perspective of another account. Discover how to share zones of records, and provide better collaboration between participants. And find out how to hide inactive containers. Weâ€™ll also share a few tips on getting the most out of CloudKit Console.

Join us as we share the latest updates to SharePlay. Weâ€™ll show you how you can start SharePlay sessions right from your app, take you through improvements to APIs to create richer experiences, and check out enhancements to GroupSessionMessenger. Weâ€™ll also explore best practices for adding SharePlay to your app.

Explore the latest updates to WKWebView, our framework for incorporating web content into your appâ€™s interface. Weâ€™ll show you how to use the JavaScript fullscreen API, explore CSS viewport units, and learn more about find interactions. Weâ€™ll also take you through refinements to content blocking controls, embedding encrypted media, and using the Web Inspector.

Learn how you can extend Safariâ€™s functionality with Safari Web Extensions. Weâ€™ll introduce you to the latest WebExtension APIs, explore non-persistent background page support â€” a particularly relevant topic if youâ€™re developing for iOS â€” and discover how you can use the Declarative Net Request WebExtensions API to block content on the web. Finally, weâ€™ll show you how to customize tabs in Safari 15.
Session notes shared by the community for the community.

Discover the latest updates to Create ML. Weâ€™ll share improvements to Create MLâ€™s evaluation tools that can help you understand how your custom models will perform on real-world data. Learn how you can check model performance on each type of image in your test data and identify problems within individual images to help you troubleshoot mistaken classifications, poorly labeled data, and other errors. Weâ€™ll also show you how to test your model with iPhone and iPad in live preview using Continuity Camera, and share how you can take Action Classification even further with the new Repetition Counting capabilities of the Create ML Components framework.
Software engineer with a strong passion for well-written code, thought-out composable architectures, automation, tests, and more.

Discover techniques for building rich, accessible web apps with custom controls, SSML, and the dialog element. Weâ€™ll discuss different assistive technologies and help you learn how to use them when testing the accessibility of your web apps.

Discover the latest updates in iPad app design. Weâ€™ll take you through improvements to search, navigation bars, edit menus, multi-selection, and more. Learn how you can make your app both more powerful and easier to use when you incorporate customizable toolbars, multi-column tables, and find and replace.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in iPad app design

abstract.text: Come along with us as MapKit enters a new dimension. Weâ€™ll show you how you can upgrade your app to use the latest map and support the highly-detailed 3D City Experience. Learn how you can visualize data using overlays while ensuring they integrate smoothly into the 3D map. Weâ€™ll also cover how to create interactive and immersive experiences with Selectable Map Features and Look Around APIs.

Notarization works in tandem with macOS to help people safely download software for their Mac outside of the App Store. Learn about the required transition from altool to notarytool and how the Xcode GUI can help you achieve better overall performance when notarizing your app. Weâ€™ll also share information about APIs for interacting with the Notary service from any internet-connected machine.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in notarization for Mac apps
Whatâ€™s new in the Photos picker

abstract.text: PHPicker provides simple and secure integration between your app and the system Photos library. Learn how SwiftUI and Transferable can help you offer integration across iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and watchOS.

Discover how the Nearby Interaction framework can help you easily integrate Ultra Wideband (UWB) into your apps and hardware accessories. Learn how you can combine the visual-spatial power of ARKit with the radio sensitivity of the U1 chip to locate nearby stationary objects with precision. Weâ€™ll also show you how you can create background interactions using UWB accessories paired via Bluetooth.

HLS Interstitials can help you create seamless transitions in video content between advertisements, other interstitials, and your HLS streams. Learn how you can optimize your ad inventory, fine-tune interstitial presentation with SNAP-IN/OUT when using HLS, and more.

Explore the latest features in Safari and WebKit and learn how you can make better and more powerful websites. Weâ€™ll take you on a tour through the latest updates to HTML, CSS enhancements, Web Inspector tooling, Web APIs, and more.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in Safari and WebKit

abstract.text: Discover the latest updates to Wallet & Apple Pay. Weâ€™ll show you how to support Orders in Wallet for your apps and websites and securely validate someoneâ€™s age and identity with the Identity Verification API. Weâ€™ll also explore PassKit support for SwiftUI, and discuss how you how you can improve your Apple Pay experience with Automatic Payments.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in Wallet and Apple Pay

abstract.text: Discover PDFKit â€” a full-featured framework that helps your app view, edit, and save PDF documents. Weâ€™ll take you through the latest features in PDFKit, including support for live text and forms, creating PDFs from images, building interactive overlays, and saving annotations.

Discover the latest updates and improvements to the Advanced Video Quality Tool (AVQT). Weâ€™ll take you through the interactive reports feature and help you learn how to identify video quality-related issues. Weâ€™ll also explore extended support for raw formats, show you how to evaluate specific scenes within a video, and explore how you can use AVQT for Linux to analyze videos on Linux servers and online in the cloud.

Learn about the latest updates to Vision APIs that help your apps recognize text, detect faces and face landmarks, and implement optical flow. Weâ€™ll take you through the capabilities of optical flow for video-based apps, show you how to update your apps with revisions to the machine learning models that drive these APIs, and explore how you can visualize your Vision tasks with Quick Look Preview support in Xcode.

Itâ€™s a SwiftUI party â€” and youâ€™re invited! Join us as we share the latest updates and a glimpse into the future of UI framework design. Discover deep levels of customization, advanced techniques for layout, elegant strategies for sharing, and rock-solid structural approaches for designing an app top-to-bottom in SwiftUI. Weâ€™ll also have some celebratory fun as we play with the latest graphical effects and explore APIs.

Discover the latest updates and improvements to UIKit and learn how to build better iPadOS, iOS, and Mac Catalyst apps. Weâ€™ll take you through UI refinements, productivity updates, API enhancements, and more. Weâ€™ll also help you explore improvements to performance, security, and privacy.

Discover the latest updates to TextKit and text views in UI frameworks. Explore layout refinements and API enhancements, learn how you can maintain compatibility across multiple OS versions, and find out how to modernize your app with TextKit 2.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in TextKit and text views

abstract.text: Discover the latest advances in Mac app development using AppKit. Weâ€™ll take you through the latest updates to SF Symbols, show you how you can elevate your interface with enhanced controls, and help you learn to coordinate your windows with Stage Manager. Weâ€™ll also explore the latest sharing and collaboration features for macOS.

Explore the latest updates to App Clips! Discover how weâ€™ve made your App Clip even easier to build with improvements to the size limit as well as CloudKit and keychain usage. Weâ€™ll also show you how to use our validation tool to verify your App Clip and automate workflows for your advanced App Clip experiences using App Store Connect.

Discover the latest updates to App Store Connect, your suite of tools to create, manage, and submit apps on the App Store. Learn about enhancements to the submission experience â€” including the ability to manage submissions in App Store Connect on iOS and iPadOS â€” as well as the newest updates to the App Store Connect API and much more.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in App Store Connect

abstract.text: Learn about the latest improvements to Safari extensions. Weâ€™ll take you through new APIs, explore per-site permissions for Safari app extensions, and share how you can make sure your extensions work great in both Private Browsing and Profiles.

Learn how to add your own tools directly into Web Inspector using the latest Web Extensions APIs. Weâ€™ll show you how to create your own tab in Web Inspector, evaluate JavaScript in the inspected page, and use the result to help you troubleshoot and identify potential problems.

Find out how you can build apps that help people manage their relationship with their device â€” all while putting privacy first. Weâ€™ll take you through the Screen Time API and share how you can use features like core restrictions and device activity reports to create great experiences while providing measurable control for the deviceâ€™s owner, parents, and guardians.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in Screen Time API

abstract.text: Join us for an exciting update on Swift-DocC and learn how you can write and share documentation for your own projects. Weâ€™ll explore improvements to Swift-DocC navigation and share how you can compile documentation for application targets and Objective-C code. Weâ€™ll also show you how to publish your content straight to hosting services like GitHub Pages.

Explore the latest updates to SF Symbols, Appleâ€™s extensive library of iconography designed to integrate seamlessly with San Francisco, the system font for all Apple platforms. Discover the latest additions to the SF Symbols library and new categories in the app. Learn about the new Automatic behavior, which chooses the rendering mode that best highlights whatâ€™s unique about the symbolâ€™s characteristics. See how to use the new Variable Color feature to make a symbol more dynamic. Weâ€™ll also learn about a more efficient way of annotating symbols with the new unified approach.

Explore enhancements to device management across Apple platforms. Improve device deployment workflows using the latest version of Apple Configurator for iPhone. Learn about identity technologies and MDM protocol updates for macOS, iOS and iPadOS. Weâ€™ll also share an exciting change in how we provide device management documentation.

doc://WWDCNotes/documentation/WWDCNotes/.title: Whatâ€™s new in managing Apple devices

abstract.text: At Apple, we believe that privacy is a fundamental human right, and protecting peopleâ€™s privacy is at the center of everything we do. Discover how our engineering teams build privacy into all of our products and developer frameworks, and learn about the technologies and patterns you can adopt in your apps to build trust and protect your customers.

Learn how you can build reliable endpoint security products like anti-virus software, endpoint detection and response, and data leakage prevention solutions for macOS. Weâ€™ll take you through the latest enhancements to Endpoint Security APIs: Learn how you can support more security events and use advanced muting capabilities in your app. Weâ€™ll also explore a standalone tool to help you perform introspection from the command line.
Xcode 14, Swift 5.7, iOS 16, macOS 13, tvOS 16, watchOS 9.
New APIs:
, and more.

Discover the latest productivity and performance advancements in Xcode 14. Weâ€™ll introduce you to the fully redesigned SwiftUI canvas experience, explore enhancements to code completion and navigation, and take you through performance improvements weâ€™ve made throughout the entire development process. Weâ€™ll also show you how you can now read and respond to feedback on your TestFlight builds without ever leaving Xcode.

Discover the latest tools to help you test your in-app purchases and subscriptions. Weâ€™ll show you how to bring your products from App Store Connect into StoreKit Testing in Xcode, learn about improvements to the transaction manager, and explore your in-app purchase flow in Xcode Previews. Weâ€™ll also take you through best practices when setting up an Apple ID for the sandbox environment, and show you how to create tests for refund requests, price increase consent, billing retry, and much more.

Bring the latest HealthKit features to your health & fitness app. Weâ€™ll show you how to capture more detailed sleep data through sleep stages, track swim-bike-run and interval workouts with the enhanced Workout API, and save vision prescriptions â€” including an image of the physical prescription â€” directly to HealthKit while preserving privacy.
